image.altText: Cyclist Melissa Hoskins smiles during an interview.

props.synopsis: Mourners have paid tribute to Perth Olympic cyclist Melissa Hoskins who died after she was struck by a car allegedly driven by her husband on December 30.

title.children: Olympic cyclist Melissa Hoskins farewelled by family and friends

image.altText: A male tennis player, holding his racquet, in all blue on a blue court, looks upset.

props.synopsis: Novak Djokovic's winning streak at the Australian Open has extended to 30 matches after he defeated Alexei Popyrin in a tense four-set battle.

title.children: 'Say it to my face': Djokovic lifts after confrontation with fan to overcome brave Popyrin

image.altText: Lightning strikes off the coast of a beach

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting warmer-than-average temperatures for much of the country in February, with wetter-than-normal conditions currently underway in central and eastern Australia expected to continue for the rest of January.

title.children: What's in store for Australia's weather for the rest of summer?

image.altText: A line of trucks at a stop

props.synopsis: Truck drivers are warning caravanners not to park in their rest stops because of the potentially devastating consequences of missing a fatigue break.

title.children: Truck drivers plead with caravanners to stay away from truck rest stops

image.altText: a man in a business suit walks outside a court building

props.synopsis: The 28-year-old is accused of causing a horrific road crash in South Australia's Mid North in October that claimed the lives of three people, including one who died in hospital a week after the collision.

title.children: Italian tourist faces court over campervan crash that claimed lives of elderly couple and daughter

image.altText: King Charles smiles and looks to the left.

props.synopsis: As King Charles seeks treatment for an enlarged prostate, his daughter-in-law faces up to two weeks in hospital after undergoing abdominal surgery.

title.children: King Charles to undergo treatment for enlarged prostate, as Kate Middleton recovers in hospital after surgery

image.altText: A woman holding a bag on her shoulder looking at the camera, in front of a queue of people

props.synopsis: More parents than ever are turning to charities for assistance to help afford school basics, from the right uniforms and shoes, to extensive textbook and stationery lists.

title.children: With costs of even public school going up, experts fear Australia's moving to a system where you 'get what you pay for'

image.altText: A line of ambulances queued up down the ramp to the emergency department at the Royal Hobart Hospital.

props.synopsis: Over the past five years, 136 people died in Tasmanian hospitals in the 24 hours after being "ramped", a parliamentary inquiry has been told. But the Health Department warns against drawing conclusions.

title.children: Tim's father was ramped at hospital with sepsis. He survived, but 136 others have died after waiting

image.altText: What does "net-zero" look like for Australia?

props.synopsis: Company directors could face legal action if they fail to produce credible emissions forecasts, under draft laws proposed by the federal government.

title.children: Companies could be held liable for 'greenwashing' emissions figures under a new proposal

image.altText: Flowers and teddy bear left near site of a car crash

props.synopsis: Australia has committed to an ambitious target of zero road deaths by 2050, but if the current trend continues, that's near impossible. So what's going wrong?

title.children: Australia thought it could cut road deaths to zero by 2050. What's gone so wrong?

image.altText: three high-rise buildings visible with trees and grass in foreground

props.synopsis: The Lachlan's Line precinct was completed in 2019, consisting of four buildings containing a total of 900 apartments, with a retail village on the ground floor.

title.children: Sydney apartment tower development 'at threat of collapse' after 'serious defects' found in concrete

image.altText: Josef Fritzl stands amid security guards

props.synopsis: A lawyers for the 88-year-old, currently serving a life sentence, say he can no longer walk unassisted and no longer poses any danger.

title.children: For 24 years, Josef Fritzl kept his daughter imprisoned in a secret cellar. Now his lawyer says he should be released

image.altText: A Chinese man carries a child at a crowded shopping mall.

props.synopsis: Demographers said the rise was also driven by the aging of the population and the widespread COVID-19 outbreaks that started in December 2022.

title.children: China's population falls for second straight year as births drop despite end of one-child policy

image.altText: A map showing the tropical low off the coast.

props.synopsis: The chance of a tropical cyclone crossing the Queensland coast next week is "significant" and a "severe impact is possible", according to the latest update from the Bureau of Meteorology.

title.children: BOM warns 'severe impact possible' if second tropical cyclone crosses the Queensland coast

image.altText: A computer generated image of the SLIM spacecraft separating from a rocket

props.synopsis: Japan is planning to land a car-sized spacecraft on the Moon this week. If SLIM succeeds, it will make history and pave the way for building landers that can explore the Solar System's  planets and moons.

title.children: Japan's chance to become the fifth nation to land on the Moon rides on SLIM's success

image.altText: A volcano with smoke coming out of it and hills in the background.

props.synopsis: As one of the most volcanically active regions on earth, Indonesia's mountains attract thousands of visitors each year. But the deaths of 24 hikers last month has prompted experts to renew warnings about the dangers of extreme tourism.

title.children: 'The risk is never zero': Despite tragedy, Indonesia's ring of fire still brings in the tourists

image.altText: Dozens of servicemen and women line the sides of a large white naval vessel docked in a harbour

props.synopsis: China denies one of its warships fired sonar blasts that injured Australian navy divers last year, while claiming a Japanese warship may have been responsible.

title.children: Beijing points finger at Japan over sonar attack on Australian warship HMAS Toowoomba

image.altText: Smoke rising from the site of a factory explosion.

props.synopsis: An explosion at a fireworks factory in central Thailand killed at least 23 people on Wednesday, according to a rescue worker.

title.children: Fireworks factory explosion kills at least 23 people in central Thailand

image.altText: the gabba stadium

props.synopsis: Former Brisbane lord mayor Graham Quirk has been tasked by newly installed Queensland Premier Steven Miles to review the 2032 Games master plan, including the controversial $2.7 billion Gabba rebuild.

title.children: Former LNP lord mayor called in by Queensland Labor government to scrutinise 2032 Olympics plans

image.altText: A middle-aged African man wearing a white-grey polo shirt stands behind a bench in a courtroom.

props.synopsis: Authorities say Paul Mackenzie, the head of the Good News International Church, ordered his followers to starve themselves and their children to death so that they could go to heaven before the world ended.

title.children: Kenyan cult leader to face murder charges over child starvation deaths

image.altText: Josh Hazlewood and Cameron Green high five

props.synopsis: Australia makes an unusual choice after winning the toss, and the West Indies gave Usman Khawaja a life. Here's the five quick hits from day one of the first Test at Adelaide Oval.

title.children: Five quick hits — An unusual decision at the toss and another crucial drop on day one at Adelaide Oval

image.altText: A light brown cow with a white face stands next to a black bull on an island.

props.synopsis: A NSW fisherman who has been taking care of the cow says it now has a bovine companion, but both seem set to stay put until their origins can be established.

title.children: Mystery deepens as bull spotted alongside cow that has been living on island for two years

image.altText: Goat in small white enclosure inside house.

props.synopsis: Police have allegedly discovered hundreds of animals at a disused property run by a volunteer animal rescue group.

title.children: Injured and dying animals allegedly found in abandoned property in 'disgusting condition'

image.altText: A close-up photo of an old man, looking out into the distance, with clouds behind him

props.synopsis: An Irish Catholic priest played an important — but largely secret — role in the conflict over Northern Ireland.

title.children: This Catholic priest was involved in plots that killed scores of people. He has no remorse

image.altText: A police officer on a boat in Karumba.

props.synopsis: A man has been charged with torture and slavery offences, following a police investigation in a remote part of Far North Queensland.

title.children: Deckhands swam through crocodile-infested waters to escape being tortured, Queensland police allege

image.altText: Storm Hunter pumps her fists after winning her second-round match at the 2024 Australian Open.

props.synopsis: Admitting she felt a "bit flat" ahead of the third and final set against Laura Siegmund, Hunter reveals how she lifted herself off the canvas to reach the third round at Melbourne Park.

title.children: The simple message that inspired Storm Hunter to achieve a career milestone at the Australian Open

image.altText: A red and white plane with damaged wing photo taken from inside another plane.

props.synopsis: The final moments of a fatal plane crash that killed two people in Melbourne's Port Phillip Bay last year have been revealed in a preliminary ATSB report into the incident.

title.children: 'Not without its risks': Final moments of last year's fatal plane crash at Melbourne's Port Phillip Bay revealed

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: A close up of a pile of SIM cards lying on a table, overlapping and showing their metal contacts

props.synopsis: Authorities say nine customers had their SIM cards illegally swapped without them knowing, and five of them together lost more than $160,000.

title.children: Telco fined $260k after SIM-swapping scam leads customers to lose thousands

image.altText: Aboriginal elder signing document

props.synopsis: Ted Carlton has long been a prominent Indigenous advocate in the Kununurra community. Now he is accused of carnal knowledge with a child under 16 when he was a teenager in the 1970s.

title.children: Kimberley elder steps down from native title group after historical carnal knowledge allegations

image.altText: image of woman with curly hair in green shirt smiling

props.synopsis: The comedian has a 97-per cent chance of contracting cancer, but taking a genetic test to shed more light on the risk could ruin her chances to obtain life insurance.

title.children: Future of genetic testing threatened by life insurance catch as Australian comedian Michelle Brasier discovers
